label: Multi-Touch Attribution Modeling
description: Algorithmic attribution across all touchpoints revealing true marketing contribution and enabling 40-70% improvement in budget allocation vs last-click models.

traditional.workflow: 1. Marketing analyst uses last-click attribution from Google Analytics (only final touchpoint gets credit). 2. Manual spreadsheet attempts to compare channel performance using siloed platform data. 3. Awareness and consideration channels (display, social, email) appear to have no ROI. 4. Budget over-allocated to bottom-funnel retargeting and branded search. 5. No visibility into cross-device or online-to-offline journey contributions.
constraints: Last-click attribution ignores 70-90% of customer journey touchpoints
Upper-funnel channels (display, social, video) appear ineffective and get de-funded
Platform silos prevent unified view (Google vs Meta vs email each claim full credit)
No cross-device tracking (mobile research → desktop purchase uncredited)
Offline conversions (in-store, phone) not attributed to digital touchpoints
Budget allocation based on incomplete/misleading attribution data

agentic.workflow: 1. Journey Tracking Agent captures complete customer journey across: all digital touchpoints (search, display, social, email, organic), cross-device paths (mobile app → desktop web → tablet), online and offline (digital ads → in-store purchase). 2. Attribution Modeling Agent applies multiple models: position-based (40% first, 40% last, 20% middle), time-decay (more recent gets more credit), data-driven algorithmic (ML determines optimal weighting). 3. Touchpoint Contribution Analysis shows incremental value of each channel. 4. Unified Reporting deduplicates conversions across platforms. 5. Budget Recommendation Agent suggests optimal allocation based on true contribution.
dataSources: Complete customer journey data across all channels
Cross-device identity resolution data
Online transaction and conversion data
Offline sales data (in-store, phone, direct mail)
Ad exposure and engagement data from all platforms
Customer lifetime value and cohort data
benefits: 40-70% improvement in budget allocation through accurate attribution
Multi-touch models reveal upper-funnel drives 50-70% of conversions (vs 0% credit in last-click)
Cross-device tracking captures 25-40% of journeys missed by single-device attribution
Online-to-offline attribution proves digital impact on in-store sales
Data-driven algorithmic models optimize channel mix for maximum ROI
Unified view eliminates platform duplication and attribution conflicts

quickWins: Implement position-based attribution as first step beyond last-click
prerequisites: Online and offline sales data integration

label: Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM)
description: Statistical modeling of marketing effectiveness including non-digital channels delivering holistic view of all marketing drivers and 30-50% optimization opportunity.

traditional.workflow: 1. Marketing team engages consulting firm to build marketing mix model annually. 2. Consultant collects 2-3 years of historical data on spend and sales. 3. Manual regression modeling done in spreadsheets over 2-3 months. 4. Static report delivered showing historical channel contribution and ROI. 5. Insights already outdated by delivery and not actionable for in-flight optimization.
constraints: Annual cadence means insights stale 11 out of 12 months
2-3 month analysis process delays decision-making
Static historical view doesn't enable real-time optimization
Manual modeling limits sophistication (linear regression only)
Expensive consulting engagements ($100k-500k per model)
No integration with media buying or budget allocation systems

agentic.workflow: 1. Data Integration Agent continuously ingests marketing spend, sales, and external factors (seasonality, macroeconomic, competitive). 2. MMM Agent builds and updates statistical models: channel contribution and ROI, saturation curves (diminishing returns), carryover effects (lagged impact), synergies between channels. 3. Scenario Planning Agent forecasts impact of budget allocation changes. 4. Optimization Engine recommends optimal marketing mix for maximum efficiency. 5. Models auto-refresh monthly with latest data for current insights.
dataSources: Marketing spend by channel (digital and offline)
Sales and revenue data (online and offline)
External factors (seasonality, weather, economic indicators)
Competitive spend and share of voice data
Media mix variables (reach, frequency, GRPs)
Product launches and promotional calendar
benefits: 30-50% optimization opportunity identified through holistic channel analysis
Monthly model updates vs annual (12x faster insights)
Includes non-digital channels (TV, radio, print, OOH) often 40-60% of budget
Scenario planning enables 'what-if' budget allocation testing
Automated modeling reduces cost 80-90% vs consulting engagements
Actionable recommendations integrate with media buying decisions

quickWins: Integrate offline spend and sales data
Build baseline MMM for top channels
prerequisites: 2+ years historical marketing spend and sales data
Statistical modeling platform or data science capability

label: Incrementality Testing & Measurement
description: Controlled experiments measuring true causal impact of marketing revealing 20-40% of attributed sales are non-incremental and redirecting budget accordingly.

traditional.workflow: 1. Marketing assumes all platform-reported conversions are incremental (wouldn't have happened without ad). 2. No testing to validate whether ads truly caused sales or just took credit. 3. Budget allocated based on attribution data that conflates correlation with causation. 4. Retargeting gets huge budget despite low incrementality (users would buy anyway). 5. No measurement of cannibalizing effect between channels.
constraints: No distinction between incremental vs non-incremental conversions
Attribution assumes causation (ad caused sale) when often just correlation
20-40% of attributed sales would have occurred without ad exposure
Over-investment in low-incrementality tactics (heavy retargeting, branded search)
No experimental framework to test true causal impact
CFO skepticism due to inability to prove incremental value

agentic.workflow: 1. Experiment Design Agent creates incrementality tests: geo-holdout (advertise in test markets, hold out control markets), PSA (Public Service Announcement) method (replace ads with PSAs), audience holdout (exclude random control group from targeting). 2. Test Execution Agent runs experiments with statistical rigor. 3. Analysis Agent measures incremental lift (sales in test vs control) and calculates true incremental ROAS. 4. Channel Comparison reveals which channels drive highest incrementality. 5. Budget Optimization redirects spend from low-incrementality to high-incrementality channels.
dataSources: Sales data by geography and audience segment
Ad exposure data (who saw ads, who didn't)
Experimental test and control group definitions
Historical sales patterns for baseline comparison
Channel spend and impression data
Statistical power and sample size calculations
benefits: 20-40% budget reallocation from non-incremental to incremental channels
Geo-holdout tests prove causal impact with 95%+ confidence
Reveals retargeting incrementality often 30-50% (not 100% as attribution implies)
Branded search incrementality testing prevents over-investment
Channel interaction effects measured (e.g., TV + digital synergy)
CFO-credible ROI measurement based on controlled experiments not correlation

quickWins: Run geo-holdout test on largest paid channel
Test retargeting incrementality via audience holdout
prerequisites: Sufficient geographic or audience scale for testing
Ability to control ad delivery by geo or audience
3-6 month test duration for statistical power

label: Customer Journey Attribution
description: Path-level attribution analysis revealing high-value journey patterns and enabling 35-55% improvement in journey optimization vs touchpoint-only view.

traditional.workflow: 1. Marketing analyst looks at individual touchpoint performance in isolation (email open rate, ad click rate). 2. No visibility into common journey paths or sequences. 3. Touchpoint optimization done without understanding role in broader journey. 4. Can't identify high-converting journey patterns to replicate. 5. Journey analysis limited to quarterly custom SQL queries by data team.
constraints: Touchpoint-only view misses journey sequence importance (order matters)
Can't identify which journey paths convert best (e.g., 'Social → Email → Search' pattern)
Optimizing individual touchpoints without journey context sub-optimal
No visibility into journey length, velocity, or common patterns
Quarterly custom analysis doesn't enable real-time journey optimization
Missing cross-channel journey orchestration opportunity

agentic.workflow: 1. Journey Mapping Agent reconstructs complete customer paths across all touchpoints and channels. 2. Path Analysis Agent identifies common journey patterns: high-converting paths (e.g., 'Display → Email → Retargeting → Purchase'), dead-end paths (high drop-off), optimal journey length and velocity. 3. Sequence Attribution credits touchpoints based on their position in successful journeys. 4. Journey Optimization Agent recommends where to add/remove touchpoints for better conversion. 5. Real-time dashboards show journey flow, conversion rates by path, and optimization opportunities.
dataSources: Complete customer journey data across all touchpoints
Touchpoint sequence and timing data
Conversion and revenue data by journey path
Journey length and velocity metrics
Drop-off and abandonment points
Customer segment and cohort data
benefits: 35-55% improvement in journey optimization through path-level insights
High-converting journey patterns identified and replicated (2-3x conversion vs average paths)
Journey sequence matters: 'Email → Search' converts 40% better than 'Search → Email'
Optimal journey length discovered (e.g., 4-6 touchpoints maximize conversion)
Dead-end paths identified and fixed (add missing touchpoints to complete journey)
Real-time journey dashboards vs quarterly custom analysis

quickWins: Map top 10 most common customer journey paths
prerequisites: Customer Data Platform with journey tracking
Sufficient journey volume for pattern detection

label: Channel Performance Analysis
description: Unified cross-channel performance analytics with role-based attribution revealing channel synergies and driving 25-45% efficiency gains.

traditional.workflow: 1. Each channel team reports their performance in silos (paid search team, email team, social team). 2. Channel metrics pulled from separate platforms and manually compiled in spreadsheets. 3. Sum of channel-reported conversions exceeds actual sales by 150-250% due to duplication. 4. No understanding of channel roles (awareness vs conversion) or synergies. 5. Budget allocation battles driven by inflated individual channel claims.
constraints: Siloed reporting creates attribution duplication (every channel claims full credit)
No unified view of cross-channel performance and interactions
Can't identify channel roles (e.g., display drives awareness, search captures demand)
Channel synergies invisible (e.g., TV + digital work better together)
Manual spreadsheet compilation error-prone and time-consuming (8-12 hours/month)
Budget allocation based on inflated metrics leads to misallocation

agentic.workflow: 1. Channel Integration Agent consolidates performance data from all channels into unified platform. 2. Role Analysis Agent identifies each channel's primary role: awareness drivers (display, video, social), consideration facilitators (email, content, organic), conversion closers (retargeting, branded search, affiliates). 3. Synergy Detection Agent measures channel interaction effects (e.g., 'TV + search delivers 30% lift vs either alone'). 4. Unified Reporting deduplicates conversions for accurate cross-channel view. 5. Optimization Agent recommends channel mix based on roles, synergies, and efficiency.
dataSources: Performance data from all marketing channels
Customer journey data showing channel sequences
Conversion and revenue data (deduplicated)
Channel spend and cost data
Channel interaction and overlap data
Lift test results for synergy measurement
benefits: 25-45% efficiency gains through optimized channel mix based on roles and synergies
Deduplicated reporting shows true conversion volume (not inflated 150-250%)
Channel role clarity: awareness channels get credit for introducing customers
Synergy detection reveals 20-40% lift from complementary channel combinations
Unified dashboards eliminate manual spreadsheet compilation (8-12 hrs saved/month)
Data-driven budget allocation replaces channel team politics

prerequisites: Data integration from all marketing channels

label: Marketing ROI Optimization
description: Predictive ROI forecasting with automated budget optimization delivering 30-60% improvement in marketing efficiency through continuous reallocation.

traditional.workflow: 1. Marketing budget allocated at start of year based on prior year spend and intuition. 2. Budget locked by channel for 12 months with minimal flexibility. 3. Quarterly retrospective ROI analysis shows underperforming channels. 4. Budget reallocation happens annually during next year's planning. 5. Missed opportunities due to inability to shift budget to high-performing channels in-year.
constraints: Annual budget lock prevents in-flight optimization (stuck with bad allocation)
Retrospective ROI analysis identifies problems after budget already spent
No predictive forecasting of ROI by channel or campaign
Budget reallocation limited to 10-20% quarterly at most (organizational friction)
Seasonal opportunities missed due to inflexible budget allocation
30-60% efficiency opportunity left on table due to static allocation

agentic.workflow: 1. ROI Forecasting Agent predicts expected ROI by channel, campaign, and audience using ML models. 2. Optimization Engine calculates optimal budget allocation across channels to maximize total ROI. 3. Budget Reallocation Agent automatically shifts spend from underperforming to outperforming channels. 4. Scenario Planning Agent forecasts impact of different allocation strategies. 5. Continuous Learning improves predictions based on actual performance outcomes.
dataSources: Historical ROI data by channel, campaign, and audience
Real-time performance and spend data
Predictive models for conversion and LTV
Market conditions and seasonality patterns
Competitive spend and share of voice data
Budget constraints and allocation rules
benefits: 30-60% improvement in marketing efficiency through continuous optimization
Predictive ROI forecasting enables proactive budget allocation
Automated budget reallocation shifts spend weekly/daily vs annual lock
Scenario planning quantifies trade-offs before making allocation decisions
Seasonal opportunities captured through flexible budget reallocation
ML-driven optimization outperforms human intuition-based allocation

quickWins: Build ROI forecasting model for top 3 channels
prerequisites: Historical ROI data by channel (12+ months)
Predictive analytics platform or ML capability
Budget management system with API access
Organizational alignment on dynamic budget reallocation
